clusters.title: Trump presses Republicans to release more Epstein files despite earlier opposition
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Supports Release of Epstein Files, Reverses Previous Stance

items.title: Trump presses Republicans to release more Epstein files despite earlier opposition
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Sunday backed Republican lawmakers’ efforts to release more files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. Trump wrote on Truth Social that “we have nothing to hide,” while accusing Democrats of fueling an “Epstein hoax” over newly surfaced emails.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Sunday backed Republican lawmakers’ efforts to release more files on sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, despite previously opposing the move. Trump wrote on Truth Social that “we have nothing to hide,” while accusing Democrats of fueling an “Epstein hoax” over newly surfaced emails.

items.title: In a shift, Trump says House Republicans should vote to release Epstein files
items.standfirst: Members of the House, including some Republicans, have forced a vote as early as Tuesday to release unclassified files held by the government.
items.content: Members of the House, including some Republicans, have forced a vote as early as Tuesday to release unclassified files held by the government.(Image credit: Steve Marcus/AP)

items.title: Trump Flips to Say House Should Vote for Epstein Files Release

items.content: 'We have nothing to hide," Trump wrote on Truth Social, after previously fighting a proposal to make more of the Epstein files public.

items.content: All Democrats and four Republican House members last week successfully brought a petition to the floor to force a vote to release the full Justice Department files on Epstein, circumventing GOP leaders.

clusters.title: Crime-weary Chile sends communist Jara and far-right Kast to presidential run-off
clusters.neutral_headline: Chile Presidential Race Heads to Runoff Between Jara and Kast

items.title: Crime-weary Chile sends communist Jara and far-right Kast to presidential run-off
items.standfirst: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97% counted, Jara had 26.71% and Kast 24.12%. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.
items.content: Chile’s former labor minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will face a presidential run-off after leading Sunday’s first-round vote, provisional results showed. With 82.97% counted, Jara had 26.71% and Kast 24.12%. The campaign has been dominated by rising violent crime blamed on foreign gangs.

items.title: Far-right candidate José Antonio Kast favourite to become Chile’s next president after first round vote
items.standfirst: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...
items.content: The ultraconservative lawyer is in pole position going into the second round election, after running a campaign with a distinctly Trumpian feel​The ultraconservative lawyer, José Antonio Kast, is in pole position to become Chile’s next leader after advancing to the second round of the South American country’s presidential election where he will face the Communist party candidate Jeannette Jara.With more than 70% of votes counted, Kast had secured about 24% of the vote in Sunday’s first round vote, having campaigned on hard-line promises to crack down on crime and immigration, while making a Donald Trump-style pledge to “put Chileans first”. Continue reading...

items.title: Communist and far-right candidates head to Chile presidential run-off
items.standfirst: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.
items.content: The Communist Party's Jeanette Jara will face far-right candidate José Antonio Kast in the second round of voting in December.

items.title: Chile's presidential race moves to runoff
items.standfirst: Chile's presidential race is set for a runoff vote on December 14 after neither of the top two candidates managed to clear the 50% threshold and secure an outright win.More to come......
items.content: Chile's presidential race is set for a runoff vote on December 14 after neither of the top two candidates managed to clear the 50% threshold and secure an outright win.More to come......

items.title: Chile heads to a tense presidential run-off between Jara and Kast
items.standfirst: Leftist labour minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will go head-to-head in December run-off.
items.content: Leftist labour minister Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast will go head-to-head in December run-off.

items.title: Chile votes for next president in contest dominated by crime and migration fears
items.standfirst: Voters face seemingly extreme choice between communist and rightwing frontrunners, who both promise to fight foreign gangsChileans began voting for a new president and parliament on Sunday, in a contest expected to favour the hard right as candidates play on popular fears over organised crime and immigration.It is the first of an expected two rounds of presidential elections, as polls show none of the candidates clearing the 50% threshold needed to avoid a runoff scheduled for 14 December. Continue reading...
items.content: Voters face seemingly extreme choice between communist and rightwing frontrunners, who both promise to fight foreign gangsChileans began voting for a new president and parliament on Sunday, in a contest expected to favour the hard right as candidates play on popular fears over organised crime and immigration.It is the first of an expected two rounds of presidential elections, as polls show none of the candidates clearing the 50% threshold needed to avoid a runoff scheduled for 14 December. Continue reading...

ai_summary: Communist Party's Jeannette Jara and far-right leader Jose Antonio Kast advance to runoff.
Jara and Kast secured the top two spots in the first round of voting.
The runoff election is scheduled for December 14.
Kast campaigned on promises to address crime and immigration.
The campaign has been dominated by concerns about rising violent crime.

clusters.title: Ecuador votes against allowing foreign military bases in country

items.title: Ecuador votes against allowing foreign military bases in country

items.content: Voters have rejected a referendum proposal, dealing a blow to President Daniel Noboa and US ambitions in the region.

items.title: Ecuador rejects return of US military bases in major setback for Noboa
items.standfirst: Ecuadorans on Sunday rejected the return of US military bases, early referendum results showed, dealing a setback to Trump-aligned President Daniel Noboa. With more than half the ballots counted, about 60% of voters opposed lifting the country’s long-standing ban on hosting foreign military facilities.
items.content: Ecuadorans on Sunday rejected the return of US military bases, early referendum results showed, dealing a setback to Trump-aligned President Daniel Noboa. With more than half the ballots counted, about 60% of voters opposed lifting the country’s long-standing ban on hosting foreign military facilities.

items.title: ‘No’ vote leads in Ecuador referendum on hosting foreign military bases
items.standfirst: Count of a third of ballots show 60 percent rejection of the proposal to host foreign military bases.
items.content: Count of a third of ballots show 60 percent rejection of the proposal to host foreign military bases.

items.title: Ecuador votes on return of US military bases to tackle drug violence

items.content: Referendum asks whether to lift constitutional ban as President Daniel Noboa seeks US help against cartels.

items.title: Ecuador votes on return of foreign military bases and how to tackle drug violence
items.standfirst: Ecuadorans went to the polls Sunday to vote on whether to allow the return of foreign military bases to the country, how to tackle drug violence and the drafting of a new constitution that could give its Trump-friendly President Daniel Noboa more power.
items.content: Ecuadorans went to the polls Sunday to vote on whether to allow the return of foreign military bases to the country, how to tackle drug violence and the drafting of a new constitution that could give its Trump-friendly President Daniel Noboa more power.

ai_summary: Ecuadorians rejected a referendum proposal to host foreign military bases.
Approximately 60% of voters opposed lifting the ban on foreign military facilities.
The referendum was a setback for President Daniel Noboa.
The vote also addressed how to tackle drug violence.
The referendum included a vote on drafting a new constitution.

items.title: End of government shutdown clears way for Epstein vote, leading to Trump-Greene dispute

clusters.title: Zelensky vows to reform Ukraine’s energy sector amid corruption storm
clusters.neutral_headline: Zelensky Announces Energy Sector Overhaul in Ukraine

items.title: Zelensky vows to reform Ukraine’s energy sector amid corruption storm
items.standfirst: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced a sweeping shake-up of Ukraine’s state energy firms this weekend, including a complete reshuffle of management at Energoatom, the state nuclear power company at the centre of a $100m embezzlement scheme uncovered by investigators.
items.content: Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky announced a sweeping shake-up of Ukraine’s state energy firms this weekend, including a complete reshuffle of management at Energoatom, the state nuclear power company at the centre of a $100m embezzlement scheme uncovered by investigators.

items.title: Zelenskyy pledges to clean up Ukraine’s energy sector amid corruption scandal
items.standfirst: President to overhaul state energy firms after $100m kickback scheme alleged by anti-corruption investigatorsVolodymyr Zelenskyy has announced a plan to clean up Ukraine’s energy sector after an $100m (£76bn) kickback scheme was alleged by anti-corruption investigators, in the worst scandal of his presidency.Over the weekend, the Ukrainian president announced an overhaul of key state energy companies including a complete change of management at Energoatom, the nuclear power operator at the centre of the alleged criminal scheme. Continue reading...
items.content: President to overhaul state energy firms after $100m kickback scheme alleged by anti-corruption investigatorsVolodymyr Zelenskyy has announced a plan to clean up Ukraine’s energy sector after an $100m (£76bn) kickback scheme was alleged by anti-corruption investigators, in the worst scandal of his presidency.Over the weekend, the Ukrainian president announced an overhaul of key state energy companies including a complete change of management at Energoatom, the nuclear power operator at the centre of the alleged criminal scheme. Continue reading...

items.title: Zelensky vows energy sector overhaul after $100m corruption scandal
items.standfirst: State-owned energy firms will be fully audited and new management brought in, the Ukrainian PM says.
items.content: State-owned energy firms will be fully audited and new management brought in, the Ukrainian PM says.

ai_summary: Ukrainian President Zelensky announced a shake-up of state energy firms.
The overhaul follows a $100 million kickback scheme allegation.
The management of Energoatom, the state nuclear power company, will change.
State-owned energy firms will undergo full audits.
The scandal is considered the worst of Zelensky's presidency.

items.title: Inside Trump’s scramble to reduce US dependence on Chinese rare-earth metals
items.standfirst: The White House has made it a top priority to return the rare-earth industry to US shores. But is it really feasible?Scott Bessent, the US treasury secretary, returned from South Carolina last week brandishing a small piece of metal, proclaiming that it was the first rare-earth magnet made in the US in a quarter of a century.It was, he indicated to Fox Business, proof that the US is ending “China’s chokehold on our supply chain”. Thanks to the South Carolina company eVAC’s new rare-earth mineral processing center, Bessent added: “We’re finally becoming independent again.” Continue reading...
items.content: The White House has made it a top priority to return the rare-earth industry to US shores. But is it really feasible?Scott Bessent, the US treasury secretary, returned from South Carolina last week brandishing a small piece of metal, proclaiming that it was the first rare-earth magnet made in the US in a quarter of a century.It was, he indicated to Fox Business, proof that the US is ending “China’s chokehold on our supply chain”. Thanks to the South Carolina company eVAC’s new rare-earth mineral processing center, Bessent added: “We’re finally becoming independent again.” Continue reading...

ai_summary: The White House is prioritizing returning the rare-earth industry to the US.
A US treasury secretary displayed a rare-earth magnet made in the US.
The US aims to end China's control over the supply chain.
A South Carolina company is opening a rare-earth mineral processing center.
The US is working to become independent in this area.
